citeinfo.title: Sleepers River Interlaboratory Comparison
citeinfo.othercit: This metadata file describes 1 of the 6 data tables published together (see Larger Work section).

citeinfo.title: Aqueous chemistry database, Sleepers River Research Watershed, Danville, Vermont, 1991-2018

descript.abstract: Three of our laboratories, which account for ~60-percent of our analytical data, have participated in the U.S. Geological Survey Standard Reference Sample project (Round Robin) laboratory intercomparison. The Round Robin is a semi-annual sample program in which more than 100 laboratories in the U.S. analyze up to 5 sets of reference samples, depending on laboratory focus and concentration ranges. Results are collated and compared to expected values to assess individual laboratory performance. This table summarizes the performance of these three laboratories for the most common analytes. Chemical analysis performance metrics for the other 15 laboratories used during this project can be found in "3. Sleepers River Laboratory Information.csv," "5. Sleepers River Replicate Statistics.csv," and "6. Sleepers River Blank Statistics.csv."
descript.purpose: Laboratory accuracy is of paramount importance and this program is an established way to track performance and identify any issues with specific analytes.

idinfo.accconst: None. Please see 'Distribution Info' for details.
idinfo.useconst: None. Users are advised to read the dataset's metadata thoroughly to understand appropriate use and data limitations.
idinfo.datacred: U.S. Geological Survey Land Change Science

attracc.attraccr: Mean relative percent difference (Mean_RPD) and median percent error (Median_PE) of USGS Round Robin interlaboratory comparisons provide a snapshot of laboratory performance at 3 of the 18 laboratories used by this project, accounting for ~60-percent of the analyses presented in "1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv." The calculations in and of themselves are determinations of accuracy. Any uncertainty lies in the analyses themselves and not in our calculations. See "Process Steps" and "Overview Description" for a detailed description of calculations and data table organization.

dataqual.complete: Dataset is considered complete for the information presented 08/01/1991-12/31/2018.

citeinfo.origin: U.S. Geological Survey, Quality Systems Branch
citeinfo.title: Results of the USGS Analytical Evaluation Program for Standard Reference Samples Distributed Semi-Annually

procstep.procdesc: Table "4. Sleepers River Interlaboratory Comparison.csv" presents summary statistics of USGS Round Robin interlaboratory comparisons conducted for three of the laboratories used by this project: the U.S. Forest Service Laboratory at Durham, NH (Fall 2012 to Spring 2020), the USGS Water Energy and Biogeochemical Budgets Laboratory at Boulder, CO (Fall 2007 to Spring 2017), and the U.S. Forest Service Laboratory at Grand Rapids, MN (Fall 2018-Spring 2020). Corresponding USGS Round Robin ID's are 560, 238, and 591 respectively. Anywhere from 5-58 additional laboratories participated in the comparisons summarized by this table. Original Round Robin results can be downloaded directly from the USGS (https://bqs.usgs.gov/srs/). Mean relative percent difference ("Mean_RPD") is calculated as ( |Reported Value-Most Probable Value| / (Reported Value + Most Probable Value) /2 ) X 100. Median percent error ("Median_PE") is calculated as ( (Reported Value - Most Probable Value) / Most Probable Value ) X 100. Note that PE is actually reported as "Pct Diff" in the original Round Robin results and what we define as "Mean_RPD" here, is not reported in the original Round Robin results at all. They are named and calculated as such to be consistent with "5. Sleepers River Replicate Statistics.csv" and to better reflect the conventional definitions of percent error and percent difference.

enttyp.enttypd: This comma delimited (CSV) table presents summary statistics by analyte of USGS Round Robin interlaboratory comparisons. NA denotes no data.

attr.attrdef: A number corresponding to a laboratory, identified in the “Laboratory” column, where the USGS Round Robin was conducted. Cross-referenced with "3. Sleepers River Laboratory Information.csv," see column "Laboratory_Key."
Laboratory where the USGS Round Robin was conducted. Cross-referenced with "3. Sleepers River Laboratory Information.csv," see column "Laboratory."

Chemical constituent for which the USGS Round Robin was conducted. Note that analyte names are presented as they appear in the original USGS Round Robin data and not as they appear in the other files of this data release.
Mean relative percent difference (RPD) where RPD=(|Reported Value-Most Probable Value|/( Reported Value + Most Probable Value)/2)X100

Median percent error (PE) where PE=((Reported Value-Most Probable Value)/(Most Probable Value))X100 This metric is actually reported as "Pct Diff" in the Round Robin results on the USGS website but is reported here as "PE" to be consistent with "5. Sleepers River Replicate Statistics.csv."

overview.eaover: This table presents summary statistics by analyte of USGS Round Robin interlaboratory comparisons conducted for three of the laboratories used by this project. Though chemistry data in "1. Sleepers River Aqueous Chemistry.csv" were assembled from 18 laboratories, these three laboratories accounted for ~60-percent of the analyses. These statistics could be considered a snapshot of performance at these particular laboratories. Mean_RPDs or Median_PEs greater than 10% indicate poor laboratory performance except for sodium, sulfate, and total nitrogen analyzed at the Durham laboratory, for which high Mean_RPDs or Median_PEs occur because measured values are close to their reporting limits. Additional metrics of chemical analysis performance can be found in "3. Sleepers River Laboratory Information.csv," "5. Sleepers River Replicate Statistics.csv," and "6. Sleepers River Blank Statistics.csv."

distinfo.distliab: Unless otherwise stated, all data, metadata and related materials are considered to satisfy the quality standards relative to the purpose for which the data were collected. Although these data and associated metadata have been reviewed for accuracy and completeness and approved for release by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS), no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the display or utility of the data on any other system or for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. Any use of trade, firm, or product names is for descriptive purposes only and does not imply endorsement by the U.S. Government.
